Speaker: phone girl
Dialogue: Beat it, Mottola.

Speaker: phone girl
Dialogue: 8720...Yes, hold on a second.  Mr. Granger, Chicago on the line.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Yeh?

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: Granger, this is Combs.  Why haven't we heard from ya?  Everybody else is in.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: We had a few problems with the Law this morning.  The Mayor promised the Jaycees to get tough on the rackets again, so he shut everybody down for a couple hours to make it look good.  Nothing serious, it just put us a little behind for the day.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: You been making your payoffs, haven't ya?

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Hell yes.  He does this every year. There's nothing to worry about.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: Okay, finish your count and get it up here as soon as you can.  I don't wanta be here all night.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Believe me, the Man's gonna be real happy.  Looks like we cleared over ten grand this week.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: We cleared 22 here.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Well, hell, you got the whole Chicago south side.  How do ya expect the eight lousy spots I've got to compete with that?

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: They did 14 grand in Evanston, 16.5 is Gary, and 20 in Cicero.  Looks like you're bringing up the rear, Granger.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: I just got the count.  We'll put

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: We'll be waitin'.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Mottola.

Speaker: granger
Dialogue: Take this up to the city on the 4:15.  They'll be waitin' for it at the clearing house.  And don't stop for no drinks.  You can get a cab down the street.

Speaker: thief
Dialogue: You fuckin' nigger-lover.  I'll get you for this someday, sucker egg.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: The wallet.  You gotta go after him. He's got all the money.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Don't worry, we got the wallet. What happened?  He get ya with the knife?

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Give it to me!  Please.  I gotta know it's all there!

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You just sit tight, old man.  We're gonna have to get you to a doctor.  I'll call a cop.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: No, no cops!

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You wanted by the law or somethin'?

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Naw, it's okay.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You're crazy carryin' that kinda money in this neighborhood.  No wonder you got hit.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You ain't goin' nowhere on that leg.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: I gotta!  Look, I run some slots down in West Bend for a mob here. I got a little behind on my payoffs so they figure I been holdin' out on 'em.  They gave me to 4:00 to come up with the cash.  I don't get it there I'm dead.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: It don't look good, gramps, it's ten of now.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: I got a hundred bucks for you and your friend if you deliver the money for me.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: I dunno.  That little mug that got ya is mad enough at me already -- what if he's out there waitin' around a corner with some friends.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: He won't know you're carryin' it. C'mon, you gotta help me out.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Sorry, pal.  I'll fix you up, call you a doc, but I ain't gonna walk into a bunch of knives for ya.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: How bout you?  I'll give you the whole hundred!

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: What makes you think you can trust him?  He didn't do shit.

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: Hey, butt out, chicken liver.  I gave him back his wallet, didn't I?  How far is this place?

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: 1811 Mason.  Put it in Box 3C.  You won't have no trouble.  There's five thousand dollars there and here's a hundred for you.

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: All right.  I'll make your drop for you, old man.  And don't worry, you can trust me.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: If that punk and his pals decide to search ya, you'll never fool 'em carryin' it there.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: What do we do?

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You got a bag or somethin?

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: How 'bout a handkerchief?

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Let me have the money.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: You better stick that other in here too, if you wanta keep it.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Just hurry, will ya.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Ain't no hard guy in the world gonna frisk ya there.

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: Thanks.  So long, partner.  Don't worry, everything's gonna be all right.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: Where to?

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: Which way is Mason?

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: About 20 blocks south.

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: Okay, go north.  The Joliet Station -- Fast.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: mottola
Dialogue: I just made the world's easiest five grand.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Jesus, what a bundle.  Did you know he was that loaded?

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Hell no, I just cut into him.  I woulda settled for pawning one of them shoes.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: 'With plenty of money and you-oo- oo, Oh baby, what I wouldn't do-oo- oo...'

Speaker: crystal
Dialogue: Hi, Hooker, you gettin' married or somethin'?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Come into a little dough.  You wanna get outa here tonight?

Speaker: crystal
Dialogue: Can't.  I got a 10 o'clock show.  I need the five bucks.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I'll spend fifty on ya.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Hooker!

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: How ya doin', Jimmy.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Ain't seen you in months, boy. Thought maybe you took a fall.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Naw, just a little hard times, that's all.  It's all over now.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: You gonna have a go here?  How 'bout a ten spot on the line here.  The 4-9 been lookin' good today.  Lotsa action on 28th Street

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Three grand on the black.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: You sure you wanna start off that big?  Bet like that could put a real dent in us.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I feel lucky tonight.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Aw, come on, Hooker, why don't you just...

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Three grand on the black, Jimmy.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Sorry, Hooker.  Good thing that ball came up red. Guy could get in trouble around here, losin' a bet that big.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Spin it again.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Spin it anyway, Jimmy.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Don't worry, pal.  I knew it was my night.

Speaker: crystal
Dialogue: Thanks for the evening, Hooker.  I can still make the 10 o'clock.  If you wanna spend 50 bucks on me again, mail it.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Aw, the hell with ya.

Speaker: greer
Dialogue: They found Mottola.  He was drunk in a dive in Joliet.  Never got on the train.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: I don't wanta hear about his day, Greer.  What happened to the money?

Speaker: greer
Dialogue: He lost it to a coupla con artists on his way outa the spot.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: greer
Dialogue: Twelve thousand.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: All right.  Better get on the phone to New York.  See what the big mick wants to do about it.  I gotta pretty good idea, though.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: Doyle, can I see you a minute?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I'm busy, Floyd.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: It's important.  We had a little trouble in Chicago today.  One of our runners got hit for 12 grand.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Which one?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: Mottola.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You sure he didn't just pocket it?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: No, we checked his story with a tipster.  He was cleaned by two grifters on 47th.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: They workin' for anybody?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: I don't know.  Could be.  We're runnin' that down now.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: All right, mark Mottola up a little and put him on a bus.  Nothin' fancy, just enough to keep him from coming back.  Get some local people to take care of the other two.  We gotta discourage this kinda thing.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Howdy, Louise.

Speaker: louise
Dialogue: Goddamn, Johnny Hooker, you're a sharp hunky in them linens.  If you wasn't so pale, I'da sworn you had class.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: Turn that down, Leroy.

Speaker: alva
Dialogue: Oh, Johnny, Luther said you was somethin' to see today.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I'll never be as good as that mark, Alva.

Speaker: alva
Dialogue: Well, we gonna hear all about it when we get back from church. Leroy, get your jacket on, boy.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You goin' to church now?

Speaker: alva
Dialogue: They been havin' late bingo down there.  I'm gonna call on the Lord for a little cash, while he's still payin' off.  Luther, you look in on that child from time to time, will ya?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Hey, Luther told me he was carrying a wad, but I didn't figure this much.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Which way did he do, Eirie?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Straight north.  He was gonna take it all and run.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: The bastard.  He can blow his nose all the way.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: You're late.  Where you been?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I had some appointments.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: How much did ya lose?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All of it.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: In one goddamn night?  What are ya sprayin' money around like that for? You coulda been nailed.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I checked the place out.  There weren't no dicks in there.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: You're a con man, and you blew it like a pimp.  I didn't teach ya to be no pimp.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What's eatin' you?  I've blown money before.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: No class grifter woulda' done it, that's all.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You think my play is bad?

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: I think it's the best...

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: ...It's the only reason I ain't quit before now.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: I'm gettin' too slow for this racket.  I done the best I'm gonna do.  You hang on too long, you start embarrassin' yourself.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What are you talkin' about?  We just took off the biggest score we've ever had.  We can do anything we want now.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: It's nothin' compared to what you could be makin' on the Big Con. You're wastin' your time workin' street marks.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Hey look.  You think I'm gonna run out on ya or somethin'?  Just cause we hit it big.  Luther, I owe you everything.  If you hadn't taught me con, I wouldn't know nothin'.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: Aw hell, you sound like some goddamn sucker.  You know everything I know.  You got nothin' more to learn from me.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: But you played the Big Con.  You said it was nothin'.  A game for flakes and mama's boys.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: And I'm tellin' ya now, you're a fool if you don't get into it.  A bigger fool than I was.  I been lookin' for this one all my life, Johnny.  Now I got a chance to step out at the top.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What the hell you gonna do with yourself?

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: Aw, I got a brother down in K.C., runs a freight outlet.  I can go halfsies with 'em!  It ain't too exciting, but it's mostly legal.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: Straighten up, kid.  I wouldn't turn ya out if ya weren't ready.  I got a guy named Henry Gondorff I want you to look up.  There ain't a better insideman alive.  He'll teach ya everything ya gotta know.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You'll take a cut of what I make, won't ya?

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: I'm out, Johnny.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: If that's the way you want it.

Speaker: coleman
Dialogue: That's the way I want it.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: How do you like that Coleman, huh? After three years.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Aw come on, it was the only thing to do.  He knew he was holdin' ya back.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: We were partners.  If it weren't for Luther I'd still be hustlin' pinball down at Gianelli's.  I don't need anything more than I got.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You ain't gonna have nothin' if you don't lay off them games of chance. There's a depression on ya know.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: There's always a depression on.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: If you saved a little, you wouldn't have to grift so much.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I like griftin'.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: You could buy yourself some things. Clothes, or a nice car...

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I don't look any good in clothes and I don't know how to drive. What else ya got to sell, Eirie?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Hi there, Snyder.  Things a little slow down at the Bunco Department tonight, eh?  Somebody lose the dominoes?

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: You scored blood money today, Hooker.  You need a friend.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Aw, find yourself a shoplifter to roll.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You can stake out my toilet if you want.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on 49th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You're crazy.  I'm not stupid enough to play for rackets money.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Not intentionally maybe, but that don't make no difference to Lonnegan. He'll swat you like any fly.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I'll square it with the fixer.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Nobody can buy you a prayer, if I put the finger on ya.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I figure your end of the score was at least 3 gees.  I want 2 no matter what it was.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: My end was only one.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Then you'll have to come up with another grand somewhere.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: You're a smart egg, Hooker.  No use dyin' for 2 grand.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: I thought you blew all your money.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I did.  That stuff I gave him was counterfeit.  They'll pinch him the first place he tries to spend it.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: What the hell you gonna do when Snyder rushes his finger right to Lonnegan?  You're committin' suicide, kid.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Aw Christ, it doesn't make no difference now.  If Snyder knows about it so does everybody else. He never gets anything first...Damn, there's no answer at Luther's.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Listen to me, Hooker.  What ever you do, don't go back to your place tonight, don't go anyplace you usually go, ya hear me?  Get outa town or somethin', but...

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: C'mon Luther, get up.  You gotta get up, Luther.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir.  Treasury Dept... I'd like to ask you a few questions.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: What for?  I haven't done anything.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station.  Have you made any purchases here today?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Yes, a ticket to Chicago.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: But I got a train to make.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: But what about all these other people?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'm sorry, really I am, but my train leaves in ten minutes.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All right, I'll give ya a break.  ...in the back and run it through right away.  We'll have you outta there in a couple minutes.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Thank you.  You don't know how much I appreciate this.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Think nothin' of it.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Excuse me, I'm looking for a guy named Henry Gondorff.  You know him?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Luther Coleman sent me.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: You Hooker?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Why didn't you say so.  I thought maybe you was a copper or somethin'.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: It's the room in the back.  He wasn't expecting you so soon though.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: The great Henry Gondorff.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Turn the goddamn thing off, will ya.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You sober?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: I can talk, can't I?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Glad to meet ya, kid.  You're a real horse's ass.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Yeh, Luther said you could teach me something.  I already know how to drink.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: I'm sorry about Luther.  He was the best street worker I ever saw.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He had you down as a big-timer. What happened?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Aw, I conned a Senator from Florida on a stocks deal.  A real lop-ear. He thought he was gonna take over General Electric.  Some Chantoozie woke him up, though, and he put the feds on me.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You mean you blew it.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Luther didn't tell me you had a big mouth.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He didn't tell me you was a fuck- up, either.  You played the Big Con since then.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: No, I lammed it around for a while while things cooled off.  Philly, Denver, Baltimore, nuthin' towns.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: But don't kid yourself, friend, I still know how.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You gonna stay for breakfast, or do you already know how to eat?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I picked something up on the way.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Lonnegan after you, too?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I don't know.  Haven't seen anybody.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You never do, kid.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: We got word from Chicago.  They got one of the grifters last night. The nigger.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: What about the other one?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: They're still looking for him.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Who's got the contract?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: Combs gave it to Reilly and Cole.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Hackers.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: They staked out the other guy's place last night, but he never showed.  They figure maybe he skipped town.  You wanna follow 'em up?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You see the guy in the red sweater over there?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Name's Danny McCoy.  No Neck McCoy we called him.  Runs a few protection rackets for Carnello while he's waiting for something bigger to come along.  Me and Danny been friends since we were six. Take a good look at that face, Floyd, cause if he ever finds out we let one lousy grifter beat us, you'll have to kill him and every other hood in Chicago who'd like to do the same thing.  You understand what I'm sayin'?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Good lad.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: You feeling all right this morning, Henry?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Fine, Billie.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: You mind opening the round a little early today?  We got some business coming in before hours.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Great little countess, that Billie. Runs a good house up there, too. One of the few left that Luciano doesn't own.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Gondorff, you gonna teach me the Big Con or not?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You didn't act much like you wanted to learn it.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I wanna play for Lonnegan.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You know anything about him?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Yeh, he croaked Luther.  What else do I gotta know.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Aw right, he runs the numbers outta the south side.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: And a packing company, a chain of Savings and Loans and half the politicians in Chicago and New York. There ain't a fix in the world gonna cool him out if he blows on ya.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I'll take him anyway.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: 'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: We'll get by without 'em.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I never played for winos.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Then you'll do it?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: These are Combs' favorite torpedoes. Riley and Cole.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: They do most of the small jobs, but Lonnegan might not wanna use 'em on you 'cause they're kinda messy.  No class.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: We got reason to believe Riley was the guy who hit Luther.  But if you see either one of these two, find yourself a crowd, or take 'em someplace you know you can handle 'em.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: But most of all let us know.  If they got a hit on you, we gotta fold up the con.  You're too exposed.  You got that?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You sure it'll be one of these two?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: No.  They're just the only ones we know of.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Set me up five more beers, will ya Danny.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: You the owner here?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Lieutenant Snyder.  Bunco.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Joliet badge, Snyder.  Don't cut much up here.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I'm lookin' for a guy on the lam from a counterfeiting rap.  Thought he mighta come in here.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Don't think so.  I know everybody in the place and I always bounce the lamsters.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: All right if I look around your lobby?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: No, but you're welcome to a free beer before you go.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I don't really need your permission.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: Lonnegan's a fast egg, Henry.  He's not gonna sit still for a standard play.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Everybody'll sit still for somethin'. What did ya find out about the train, Eddie?

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: He's been taking the 8:10 Century Limited outa New York on Friday and getting in here early Saturday morning.  He usually stays a day to check on his policy operations, and then flies back.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Wonder why he doesn't fly both ways.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: The porters say he runs a braced card game in one of the cars.  $100 minimum, straight poker.  Last time he pulled in here ten grand heavier than he left New York.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Fancies himself a gambler, huh?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Lotta plungers ride that train just to play him.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: See J.J., he's slowly down already.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Which way are the rooms?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Who told ya this guy was in here?

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Nobody.  I just know what kinda women he likes.  I'm gonna check all the joyhouses till I find him.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Maybe I could help ya if ya told me his name.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I think I'll keep that to myself. Which way are the rooms?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: Right through there.  But I wouldn't go in there if I were you.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: What are ya gonna do, call the cops?

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: I don't have to.  You'll be bustin' in on the Chief of Police just up the hall.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Keep your nose clean, lady.  He can't spend all his time here.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: I think we ought to play him on the Rag.  It's the tightest game we got, and it's not all over the papers yet.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: No good, J.J.  You're not gonna con stocks to a banker.  Lonnegan's too smart for that.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: What are you going to do, con the payoff to a gambler?

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: Twist is right.  It won't work.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: We'll use the wire.  Never known a gambler who wouldn't like to beat the ponies.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: The wire is ten years outa date.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: That's why he won't know it.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: I'm not sure I know it.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: We'll give him the hook on the train, and play him here.  You think I can get in that poker game, Eddie?

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: All you gotta do is show up with some money and look like a fool.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: I also gotta win.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: By the way, any of you guys been passing off any green goods lately?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Billie, if that Dick comes in again, stall him till I can get a look at him.  And let me pay ya for these beers.

Speaker: billie
Dialogue: What are you talking about?  It's on the house.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Naw, I want ya to have this.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Don't look at it till ya go to bed though or it'll turn to paper.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: Looks all right.  It's big enough and off the street.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: I don't know.  This is kinda short notice.  I'm not sure we can get it all done by Saturday.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: Got to.  Gondorff's ridin' the mark in from New York on the Century.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: We'll take it.  You manage the building at the end of the alley?

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: For fifteen years.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: I'll need a room over there that faces this way.  How much a week?

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Only rents by the month.  Two hundred and fifty for the two of them.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: This is the last time I expect to see you down here.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Never heard of the place.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: Been a while since I stocked a wire store.  Not many mobs playing that anymore.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: All we need is the bookie setup for now.  We'll worry about the telegraph office later.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: All right, I'll rent ya everything I got in the warehouse for two grand.  That'll give ya phones, cages, blackboards and ticker gear. You supply the guys to move 'em. If you want a counter and bar, that's another grand.  I don't know where the hell I'm gonna get 'em though.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: C'mon, you can do better than that. We ain't no heel grifters.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: You want the stuff tomorrow or don't ya?  It's gonna take hours just to clean it up.  Besides, Gondorff's still a hot item.  Where am I gonna be if he gets hit?

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: Just give us what ya can, Benny. We'll send a truck down.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You wanna work flat rate or percentage?

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: Who's the mark?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Doyle Lonnegan.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: Flat rate.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Guy in the blue pinstripe and grey fedora.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He's not as tough as he'd like to think.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Neither are we.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: I hear there's a friendly poker game on this train tonight.  You know anything about that?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: A little.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You think you could get me in that game?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I don't know.  There's usually a waiting list.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: That'll get you first alternate, sir.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I'll see what I can do.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: How ya doin', Lacey.

Speaker: lacey
Dialogue: Good to see ya again, Twist.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: Twist!  When did you get back in town?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Coupla days ago.  I'm workin' a big one with Gondorff on the North Side.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Listen Duke, we're setting up a wire store.  I need a twenty man boost right away.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: I got twenty or so in here tonight. Take your pick.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: These guys have gotta be the quill, Duky.  We can't afford to rank the joint.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: Get me the sheet, Jake.  Let's see who's in town.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: Twist, you know this guy?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: No.  Never saw him before.  He's a dick, though.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Hello, Snyder.  What are you doin' up here?

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: I'm on vacation.  You seen your friend lately?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Yeh, he packed it in and enrolled in detective school.

Speaker: snyder
Dialogue: You see him, you tell him to pay his debts before I get him.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: Paltrow, Sterling, Furey, and the Big Alabama are in from New Orleans. Fiskin and the Boone Kid from Denver, and Phillips, Barnett and Limehouse Chappie from New York. Those and the guys outside should give ya 30 or so to choose from.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Good, have 'em down at Stenner's old Pool Hall before 3:00.  We're gonna run through the route tonight.

Speaker: boudreau
Dialogue: Okay, Twist, but you know if this blows up, I can't do ya no good downtown.  Gondorff is Federal.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Don't worry about it, pal.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: You in?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Yeh, I think so.  I gave the kay- ducer a C-note.  You find out the deck?

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: He usually plays with a Royal or a Cadenza.  I got you one of each.  He likes to cold deck low, 8's or 9's.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Nice work, J.J.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Keep your mitts off me, ya big lug. If I'da wanted you handlin' me I woulda asked ya.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: She got him clean.  He hasn't missed it.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Fifteen grand.  Looks like he's expecting a big night.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He's waitin' for you in the card room.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Let him wait.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You just worry about your end, kid.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: If we ever get to it.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Where the hell is this guy?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I don't know.  He said he'd be here.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: All right, let's start without him. Mr. Clemens, give me the cards.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Sorry I'm late boys.  I was takin' a crap.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Mr. Shaw is a bookmaker from Chicago.  Mr. Shaw, meet Mr. Clayton from Pittsburgh, Mr. Jameson, Chicago, Mr. Lonnegan, New York and Mr. Lombard, Philadelphia.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Straight poker, gentlemen.  100 dollar minimum, table stakes.  We assume you're good for your debts.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Mr. Shaw, we usually require a tie at this table.  If you don't have one, we can get ya one.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Yeh, that'd be real nice of ya, Mr. Lonneman.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Lonnegan.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Name's Curly Jackson.  I worked for Gad Bryan outa Baltimore.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You ever played the Wire, Curly?

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Used to rope for it long ago.  I can shill, mark board, anything you want.  I don't run with riffraff and I only drink on weekends.  Me specialty is an Englishman.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: All right, Curly, you're in.  We got a rack of suits over there. Get yourself a nice tweed one.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: That's all right.  I got all my own stuff.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: See ya and raise three.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: See and raise five.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Five and call.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Tough luck, Lonnihan, but that's what you get for playin' with your head up your ass.  Couple more like that and we can all go to bed early, huh boys.

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: We bought ya a tap into Moe Anenberg's wire.  He's got eyes at every track in the country.  You'll get race results, odds, scratches, pole positions, everything; and just as fast as Western Union gets 'em.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: Does J.J. know how to use this thing?

Speaker: garfield
Dialogue: All he's gotta do is read.

Speaker: duff
Dialogue: Buck Duff.  I was in Maxwell's boost in Troy.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You the Duff that didn't come up with his end when Little Jeff was sent up?

Speaker: duff
Dialogue: Wasn't no problem a mine.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: He was a con man, wasn't he?

Speaker: duff
Dialogue: He was a tear-off rat.  He got what he deserved.  No sense helpin' pay his bills.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Shove off, Duff.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Names's Joe Eirie.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You played for any particular mobs?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You know the Wire at all?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: No...I never played no Big Con before.  But Luther Coleman was a friend a mine.  I thought maybe there was something I could do.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You get that nose in Duke Boudreau's tonight?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: You got moxie, Eirie.  Get yourself a suit.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Pass.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Two and call.

Speaker: jameson
Dialogue: Well, I'm out.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Don't worry about it, pal.  Lemongan here wouldn'ta let you in the game if you weren't a chump.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I've had enough of your lip, Shaw.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Just take it easy there, Larrabee.

Speaker: jameson
Dialogue: Let's take a break for a couple minutes and cool off.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I've had it with that bum, Floyd. Stack me a cooler.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: You've only been playin three hours, Doyle.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I don't care.  Load me a deck.  Set it up for threes and nines.  I'll cut it in on his deal.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: What do ya want the others to get?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Nothin'.  They gotta be outa there early.  I'm gonna bust that bastard in one play.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: Fold.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: See, and raise the rest.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Call.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Well that's all for me tonight, boys.  I'm gonna leave ya some cab fare.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You owe me 15 grand, pal.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I guess I left it in my room.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You come to a game like this, you bring your money.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: All right, buddy, I'm gonna send a boy by your room in five minutes, and you better have that jack, or it's gonna be all over Chicago that your name ain't worth a dime.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: How'd ya do?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Well we got some workin' money anyway.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Okay, kid, you're on.  But I gotta tell ya, its a hard act to follow.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: I know I give him four threes.  We can't let him get away with that.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: What am I supposed to do?  Call him for cheating better than me?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: My name's Carver.  Mr. Shaw sent me.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Your boss is quite a card player, Carver.  How does he do it?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He cheats.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I couldn't find my wallet.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Yeh, he knows that.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: He hired a dame to take it from ya.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You were set up, Lonnegan.  Shaw's been planning to beat your game for months.  He was just waiting for you to cheat him so he could clip ya.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I could have you put under this train for this, errand boy.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: So could Shaw.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Then why the rat?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Cause I'm tired of bein' his nigger.  I want you to help me break him.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: C'mon, I'll give ya a lift home.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: What's the matter?  You gotta get back to Shaw?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Naw, he picked up some jane in the bar.  Can't see him till morning anyway.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: All right, then.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Why me?  Shaw probably has lotsa enemies to choose from.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I need somebody respectable...but not completely legit.  What I'm gonna do isn't very legal.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I'm a banker, friend.  That's legit in this state.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All you gotta do is place a bet for me at Shaw's place.  I'll supply all the money and the information.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: If you help me out, I'll pay ya back the money you owe Shaw, myself.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: That's worth fifteen grand to ya?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Maybe a couple million.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You're dreamin', kid.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: 660 Marshall Street.  Tomorrow at 12:30, if you're interested.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: If I'm not there by quarter of, I'm not coming.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: No signs of trouble?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What do ya mean?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You know, somebody tailin' ya.  A torpedo or somethin'.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: No, not a thing.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You think he'll show?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Did he say he wouldn't?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: He'll show.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Eddie, cut that out, will ya.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Carver?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You should always look to the back too, kid.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I was afraid you weren't gonna come. We haven't got much time.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Get on with it then.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All you do is take this two grand across the street to Shaw's place and bet it on that pony.  There's nothin' to it, but don't take too much time.  We only have 3 or 4 minutes after you get the call.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You're not gonna break him with a $2,000 bet.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: This is just a test.  The big one comes later.  Be careful with that though, it's all I got.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: And you were gonna pay me back?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I am after this race.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I gotta get back before Shaw misses me.  Good luck.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: We're waitin' for a call.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Bluenote at 6 to 1 on the nose.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: Look at that.  He's got four apes with him.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: That's what I like about these guys, J.J... They always got protection against things we'd never do to 'em.

Speaker: sheet writer
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Ruth, 20,000 on Dancing Cloud.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Never get enough, huh pal?  I'd think you'd get tired of losin', Honnigan.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: The name is Lonnegan.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Make sure you see cash from this guy, Eddie.  He's got the name for bettin' money he don't have.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Two-thousand on Bluenote.

Speaker: niles
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Ladies and Gentlemen.  This is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the second race at Belmont in New York. A mile and 1/8.  Four year olds and up.  And they're off!

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Around the first turn it's a War Eagle first by a length, Jail Bate second by one and a half, Dancing Cloud third by a half on the outside, followed by Lucky Lady, Mojo, Wits' End and Bluenote.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: That's not where we want him to sit.

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: C'mon War Eagle.  That Dancing Cloud's a hell of a finisher.  War Eagle's gonna have to open up a little more on 'em.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You know anything about a horse named Bluenote?

Speaker: eirie kid
Dialogue: Naw, he's never done much.  Probably in here just to round out the field. War Eagle's where you wanna have your money.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Into the clubhouse turn, it's War Eagle by two lengths, Dancing Cloud has moved up to second by a half, Lucky Lady is third by three followed by Jail Bait, Mojo, Bluenote and Wits' End.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You really picked a winner, kid.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Give 'em a little time.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Into the backstretch it's War Eagle still by a length, Dancing Cloud closing on the inside, is second by two, Lucky Lady is third by one and a half, followed by Bluenote, Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You're doin' great, Eirie.  He loves ya.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Into the far turn, it's Dancing Cloud now by half a length, War Eagle is second by two, Bluenote is third by a half and moving fast on the outside.  Lucky Lady is fourth by four lengths, followed by Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Coming down the stretch, it's Dancing Cloud by one length, War Eagle and Bluenote are neck and neck by two.  Now it's Dancing Cloud, Bluenote and War Eagle.  Dancing Cloud and Bluenote head to head...

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  It's Bluenote by a nose.  Dancing Cloud is second by two, War Eagle third by three and a half.  Time for a mile and 1/8, 2:01 and 6/10 seconds.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Bloody awful.  Who in blazes is Bluenote?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: War Eagle's where you want to have your money, huh?

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Show this bum out.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Go on, ya goddamn ninny.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: And tell him not to bring his garbage men in here no more.  This is a class joint.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: He's gaffed, kid.  He should start coming to you now.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?

Speaker: riley
Dialogue: We missed him.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You weren't hired to miss him.

Speaker: riley
Dialogue: There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?

Speaker: riley
Dialogue: I don't know.  He took it hard.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: All right, get outa here.  You're outta work.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: We'll put Salino on it.  I need somebody careful.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: Salino?  Why waste our best people on a small-time job like this?  It ain't no heavy gee we're after. The guy's a five and dime grifter.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Then why ain't he dead?

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: They didn't think he'd be so cagey, that's all.  They'll get him next time.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Use Salino.  It'll take a little longer, but there won't be any holes in it.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: And tell Cole I wanta see him when he gets in.

Speaker: combs
Dialogue: He's not comin' in.  Not to get bounced off a job anyway.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: He had his chance and all he did was shoot up a rooming house.  Made a lotte noise and woke up a few cops, but didn't hit nothin'.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: This is Salino's job now, Vince. If Cole wants to muscle in on it, that's his business.  But he's breakin' the rules and when Salino finds out about it, I can't feel sorry for what's gonna happen to him.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Well, what did I tell ya?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You're a lucky man, all right.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Lucky, hell.  I could do it every day.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Why don't ya then.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: 'Cause it's better to do it all at once.  We're puttin' down 400 grand next week.  At 5-1 we make 2 million. Twenty per cent of that is yours if ya stick with us.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You got a system, Carver?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You stayin' in or not?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I'm in.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: It's foolproof.  We got a partner downtown runs the central office of the Western Union.  Race results from all over the country come in there and go right across his desk on their way to the bookies.  All he does in hold them up a couple minutes until he can call us and get a bet down on the winner.  Then he releases the results to the bookies and we clean up on a race that's already been run.  It can't miss, unless the Western Union Dicks get onto it.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You got the 400 grand yet?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Not yet, but...  Hey, there's only a grand here.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: I think we oughta place another bet tomorrow.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: What is this?  That's my money. You tryin' to muscle me?

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: If your system's as foolproof as you say, you'll get even more.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: Let me talk to him.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law.  C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Four o'clock tomorrow.  Pick me up at Dewey Lyle's.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Twist?  I told him the tale.  He wants to see ya.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: All right, when?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Tomorrow, after 4:00.  Stay inside, I'll come in and get ya.  And be hard on him for a while; he's talking money.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Okay, Tootsie.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Well you found him again and we're gonna have to do somethin' about it. What else haven't ya been tellin' me?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Nothin'.  I told ya everything there is.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Then why'd ya move outa your room?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: It was too noisy.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You can't play your friends like marks, Hooker.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You know how easy it'd be for one of Lonnegan's guys to nail you?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: All we need is a couple days, Henry. A couple days and we'll get Lonnegan down and stomp on 'em.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: You just won't learn, will ya. Hell, you come in here, I teach you stuff maybe five guys in this world know, stuff most grifters couldn't do even if they knew it, and all you wanna do is run down a bullet.  You're just like all them new jerks. Lotsa nerve and no brains.  And ten years from now when me and the others are through and you dumb guys are all dead there won't be one gee left who knows the Big Con was anything more than a way to make a livin'.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: A couple days; that's all I'm askin'.  I can stay clear that long.

Speaker: gondorff
Dialogue: Christ, they'll probably miss you and hit me.

Speaker: loretta
Dialogue: You done?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Yeh, I guess I shoulda had the meat loaf.

Speaker: loretta
Dialogue: It isn't any better.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Where's June today?

Speaker: loretta
Dialogue: She don't work here no more.  I'm fillin' in for a couple days... till I can get a train outa here.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Where you goin'?

Speaker: loretta
Dialogue: I don't know.  Depends what train I get on.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Excuse me.  We're here to paint Mr. Harmon's office.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: Mr. Harmon's office?  Hold on just a second.

Speaker: lonnegan
Dialogue: What happened to your face?

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Had a little fight with a raggle down on 13th.  She got me with her ring.

Speaker: harmon
Dialogue: Brigham signed it all right.  I can't understand why he didn't tell me.

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: Ah, he's like all them supervisors. They think they're too good for regular people.  He says he was in here a while ago and the place was a mess.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: We'll try and hurry so we don't keep you out of your office too long.

Speaker: harmon
Dialogue: Why can't I work with you in there?

Speaker: singleton
Dialogue: Look pal, we gotta cover the floor, the furniture, everything, so we don't spill on nothing.  Now if you wanta sit in there with a tarp over your head, you're welcome to it.

Speaker: harmon
Dialogue: All right, how long will you be?

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Hour or two at the most.  We do good work.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: We'll go to the side door.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Les, I got Mr. Lonnegan with me. He wants to see you a second.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: What the hell's the matter with you. We coulda met at a club or somethin'.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: I thought it might be good for him to see the setup.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Well we can't talk in here.  They're having the place painted.

Speaker: twist
Dialogue: Miss Barnes, I'm going home a little early today.  Tell anyone that calls that they can reach me here in the morning.  Thank you.

Speaker: twist
